isis.stitle: Recall 95504 - 9200, 9300, 9400 and Glider Pro Sleeper Models with Swivel Driver and Passenger Seats

recall.subject: 9200, 9300, 9400 and Glider Pro Sleeper Models with Swivel Driver and Passenger Seats

defect.para: This Recall applies to 9200, 9300, 9400 and Glider Pro Sleeper models built from 04/26/1994 through 05/09/1995 with swivel seat codes 16JVR, 16JVS, 16JVT, 16JVU, 16KRG, 16KRN, 16RRE, 16RRG, 16RRH and 16RRJ.

The swivel driver seat, and swivel passenger seat, if so equipped, are being recalled to correct a design deficiency. The attachment parts between the upper and lower portions of the seat swivel assembly are inadequate to insure that the assembly will stay together with normal use. Vibration can cause the attaching bolts to work loose and fall out. Should the attaching bolts fall out, the seat swivel assembly would separate and there would be nothing to hold the seat in place.

para.emph: In the event this should happen while the vehicle is in motion, it could possibly cause the operator to lose vehicle control and could possibly result in an accident causing personal injury or property damage.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE DRIVER'S SEAT
svcproc.para: The seats will be modified by installing a new swivel stop plate, a spacer between the upper and lower swivel assembly and longer mounting bolts with a patch lock. See Figure 1, Figure 2, and Figure 3.

step1.para: Remove seat belts at seat. Remove driver's seat and suspension assembly from vehicle and place upside down on an appropriate clean work surface (table or workbench) with seat back hanging over the edge so that suspension assembly will lay flat.
Remove air line from air spring.
Raise seat suspension to its most extended (highest) position and lock in position with vice grips by clamping scissors mechanism to lower suspension (see Figure 2).

para.emph: Two types of suspensions were used on the swivel seat. Approximately 200 early production assemblies built prior to 08/01/1994 used 50 ball bearings and did not use a plastic ball bearing spacer. Assemblies built since then use 12 ball bearings with a plastic ball bearing spacer. Reference Figure 3. Visually inspect suspension between Items 1 and 10 to determine which version of suspension is on the seat.

step2.para: If the suspension does not contain Item 11, plastic ball bearing spacer and the bearing track is filled with 50 bearings, Item 12, proceed to Step 5. Kit number 8900057R91 will be required to repair the swivel suspension on this seat.

If the suspension has Item 11, plastic ball bearing spacer and the bearing track has 12 ball bearings, Item 12, proceed to Step 9. Kit number 8900056R91 will be required to repair the swivel suspension on this seat.

step1.para: Note position of Item 3, Figure 1. During reassembly, Item 8, provided in parts kit and as shown in Figure 3, must be oriented the same as was Item 3. Remove Items 2, 3, 4, and 5. Discard Items 2 and 3 only.

Reference Figure 3. Separate swivel assembly, Item 1, by lifting lower suspension assembly, Item 10. Inspect for missing bearings, Item 12, and replace missing bearings if necessary from parts kit. Place lower suspension, Item 10, back onto swivel assembly, Item 1.
Reference Figure 3. Install Items 6, 5, 4, 8, and 9. Items 6, 8 and 9 are provided in parts kit along with other items that will not be used.

note.para: Item 5 removed in Step 5 may or may not have flanges as depicted in Figure 1. If the part has flanges, orient the short flange toward Item 4, otherwise orientation is not necessary. There are two pieces of Item 6 provided in parts kit each having a different thickness; use the thinner of the two parts only. Item 7 provided in parts kit should not be used; use old part, Item 5, which is thinner. The use of dowel pins may be helpful in aligning bolts, Item 9, to attachment nuts. Torque Item 9 to 162 - 198 INCH-POUNDS.

step1.para: Proceed to Step 12.

Note position of Item 3 in Figure 1. During reassembly Item 8, provided in parts kit and as shown in Figure 3, must be oriented the same as Item 3 was. Remove and discard Items 2, 3, 4, and 5 as shown in Figure 1.

Reference Figure 3. Separate swivel assembly, Item 1, by lifting lower suspension assembly, Item 10. Inspect guide plate, Item 11, for damage and/or missing bearings, Item 12. If necessary, replace guide plate with new plate and bearings from parts kit. Place lower suspension, Item 10, back onto swivel assembly, Item 1.

Reference Figure 3. Install new Items 6, 7, 8 and 9 from parts kit. Note that Item 7 has two different flange lengths and the short flange should be oriented toward Item 8. Also the use of dowel pins may be helpful in aligning bolts, Item 9, to attachment nuts. Torque Item 9 to 162 - 198 INCH-POUNDS.
Inspect air lines and repair if necessary.
Route air lines as shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2. Reconnect air line to air spring.
Unblock suspension and check for proper air and swivel function.
Re-install seat assembly in vehicle. Torque seat base floor mounting bolts to 155 to 190 INCH-POUNDS.
Re-install seat belts back onto seat and torque mounting bolts to 25 to 35 FOOT POUNDS.

Remove seat belts at seat. Remove passenger seat and suspension assembly from vehicle and place upside down on an appropriate clean work surface (table or workbench) with seat back hanging over the edge so that suspension assembly will lay flat.
Remove air line from air spring.
Reference Figure 4. Remove and save Items 2, 3, 4, 5, 14, and 15. Remove base, Item 16, and set aside.

para.emph: Two types of suspensions were used on the swivel seat. Approximately 100 early production assemblies built prior to 08/01/1994 used 50 ball bearings and did not use a plastic ball bearing spacer. Assemblies built since then use 12 ball bearings with a plastic ball bearing spacer. Reference Figure 6. Visually inspect suspension between Items 1 and 17 to determine which version of suspension is on the seat.

step2.para: If the suspension does not contain Item 18, plastic ball bearing spacer and the bearing track is filled with 50 bearings, Item 19, proceed to Step 5. Kit number 8900057R91 will be required to repair the swivel suspension on this seat.

If the suspension has Item 18, plastic ball bearing spacer and the bearing track has 12 ball bearings, Item 19, proceed to Step 9. Kit number 8900056R91 will be required to repair the swivel suspension on this seat.

step1.para: Note position of Item 7, Figure 4. During reassembly, Item 12, provided in parts kit and as shown in Figure 6, must be oriented the same as was Item 7. Remove Items 6, 7, 8, and 9. Discard Items 6 and 7 only.

Reference Figure 6. Separate swivel assembly, Item 1, by lifting lower suspension assembly, Item 17. Inspect for missing bearings, Item 19, and replace missing bearings if necessary from parts kit. Place lower suspension, Item 17, back onto swivel assembly, Item 1.
Reference Figure 6. Install Items 10, 9, 8, 12, and 13. Items 10, 12 and 13 are provided in parts kit along with other items that will not be used.

note.para: Item 9 removed in Step 5 may or may not have flanges as depicted in Figure 4. If the part has flanges, orient the short flange toward Item 8, otherwise orientation is not necessary. There are two pieces of Item 10 provided in parts kit each having a different thickness; use the thinner of the two parts only. Item 11 provided in parts kit should not be used; use old part, Item 9, which is thinner. The use of dowel pins may be helpful in aligning bolts, Item 13, to attachment nuts. Torque Item 13 to 162 - 198 INCH-POUNDS.

step1.para: Proceed to Step 12.

Note position of Item 7 in Figure 4. During reassembly Item 12, provided in parts kit and as shown in Figure 6, must be oriented the same as Item 7 was. Remove and discard Items 6, 7, 8, and 9 as shown in Figure 4.

Reference Figure 6. Separate swivel assembly, Item 1, by lifting lower suspension assembly, Item 17. Inspect guide plate, Item 18, for damage and/or missing bearings, Item 19. If necessary, replace guide plate with new plate and bearings from parts kit. Place lower suspension, Item 17, back onto swivel assembly, Item 1.

Reference Figure 6. Install new Items 10, 11, 12 and 13 from parts kit. Note that Item 11 has two different flange lengths and the short flange should be oriented toward Item 12. Also the use of dowel pins may be helpful in aligning bolts, Item 13, to attachment nuts. Torque Item 13 to 162 - 198 INCH-POUNDS.
Inspect air lines and repair if necessary.
Route air lines as shown in Figure 4 .
Reference Figure 4. Re-install Items 16, 14, 15, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Torque Item 14 to 16 - 20 FOOT POUNDS. Torque Items 5 and 15 to 22 - 28 FOOT POUNDS.
Be certain air lines are routed to air spring as shown in Figure 5. Reconnect air line to air spring.
Check for proper air and swivel function.
Re-install seat assembly in vehicle. Torque mounting bolts to 155 to 190 INCH-POUNDS.
Re-install seat belts back onto seat and torque mounting bolts to 25 to 35 FOOT POUNDS.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward. The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair the vehicle as soon as possible.
